[[Sasebo Naval District]] |unit= |battles=[[Russo-Japanese War]] |awards= |family= |laterwork= }} {{Japanese name|Matsushita}} {{nihongo|'''Hajime Matsushita'''|松下 元|Matsushita Hajime|August 10, 1884 – December 1, 1953}} was a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] naval officer and educator. ==Career== A native of [[Fukuoka Prefecture]], Matsushita graduated from the 31st class of the [[Imperial Japanese Naval Academy]] in 1903. He was assigned to serve on the cruiser {{ship|Japanese cruiser|Matsushima||2}} during the early stages of the [[Russo-Japanese War]] of 1904-1905, and was on the cruiser {{ship|Japanese cruiser|Yakumo||2}} during the decisive [[Battle of Tsushima]]. After the end of the war, he served on the cruiser {{ship|Japanese cruiser|Hashidate||2}} from November 1905 to October 1906. After graduation from the Naval Artillery School, he returned to ''Yakumo'' as a lieutenant. He then served as gunnery officer aboard the {{ship|Japanese cruiser|Takao|1888|2}}, followed by the battleship {{ship|Japanese battleship|Satsuma||2}}. He was subsequently [[Chief of staff (military)|Chief of staff]] to the [[IJN 1st Fleet]]. In May 1914, he graduated from the 12th class of the [[Naval War College (Japan)|Navy Staff College]] as a lieutenant commander. After a posting as gunnery officer on the cruiser {{ship|Japanese cruiser |Aso||2}}, he was sent to [[London]] in October 1917 as a [[military attache]]. Matsushita was promoted to commander while in London, and after his return in December 1919, was assigned to the staff of the [[IJN 4th Fleet]].Nishidah, ''Materials of the Imperial Japanese Navy'' In January 1921, Matsushita served as chief secretary to [[Ministry of the Navy of Japan|Minister of the Navy]] Admiral [[Katō Tomosaburō]]. In December 1922, he was promoted to captain, and given his first command, that of the cruiser {{ship|Japanese cruiser|Tenryū||2}}. After a posting to the Naval Personnel Bureau, he returned to sea as captain of the battleship {{ship|Japanese battleship|Kongō||2}} in December 1925. Matsushita was promoted to rear admiral in December 1927.Stocker, Donald J. (2003). {{Google books|KN-oJ_5Gy7UCs|''Girding for Battle,'' p. 138.|page=138}} As Commandant of the Imperial Japanese Naval Academy in the early-1930s, Matsuhita is credited with devising the [[Gosei (meditation)|''Gosei'']] or "Five Reflections".Smith, Peter C. (2006). {{Google books|ma1teOqjMNQC|''Fist from the Sky: Japan's Dive-Bomber Ace of World War II,'' p. 63.|page=63}} These words became traditional precepts of cadets at the Imperial Japanese Naval Academy. Every evening cadets were expected to [[meditation|meditate]] on these inter-related questions.Kennedy, Maxwell T. (2009). {{Google books|SAbIZK2hJLwC|''Danger's Hour,'' p. 91.|page=91}} The [[Japan Maritime Self Defense Force]] (JMSDF) continues to use of the ''Gosei'' as a self-reflective exercise. Matsushita was promoted to vice admiral in December 1932. He subsequently served as Commander in Chief of the Training Fleet from October 1933, Commander of the [[Maizuru Naval District]] from November 1934, and Commander of the [[Sasebo Naval District]] from March 1936 before retiring in March 1937. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * Kennedy, Maxwell Taylor.
